title: Coldrum Long Barrow Walking Route

images.title: Alan Simkins / Coldrum Long Barrow
images.caption: Looking east from the barrow, which has collapsed down the hill.

images.title: David Anstiss / The Coldrum Trail enters Ryarsh Wood
images.caption: The Coldrum Trail enters Ryarsh Wood. It enters woodland via a stile on Workhorse Road, and leads to Coldrum Lane.

images.title: Chris Gunns / Track leading to Park Farm from Coldrum Long Barrow
images.caption: Track leading to Park Farm from Coldrum Long Barrow

images.title: Simon Knights / Coldrum Long Barrow - Hartley Morris Dance at Sunrise
images.caption: Hartley Morris Dance at Sunrise. This is the Hartley Morris Men dancing at 05:32 Sunrise at the Coldrum Long Barrow on 1st May 2009. The Hartley Men have been doing this every year since 1976.

images.title: Chris Gunns / Part of Coldrum Long Barrow
images.caption: Part of Coldrum Long Barrow

images.title: David Anstiss / Visitor Centre in Trosley Country Park
images.caption: Visitor Centre in Trosley Country Park

description: This circular walk visits the ancient Coldrum Long Barrow before exploring the woodland trails in Trosley Country Park. The Long Barrow is about 3,000 years old and the only one in the Medway Valley to remain virtually intact. You can start the walk from the Coldrum car park located just to the east of the village of Trottiscliffe. From here you can pick up trails heading south east to the Long Barrow. There's also some fine views over the surrounding North Downs countryside here. The route then skirts the edge of Ryarsh Wood before turning north to join with the North Downs Way. Follow the waymarked trail west and it will take you into Trosley Country Park. There's a series of waymarked walking trails to follow through the attractive woodland of the park. After exploring the park the route then heads towards Trottiscliffe before returning to the car park.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The George Inn in Trottiscliffe is a good choice for some refreshments on the walk.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The country paths and woodland trails on the walk are good for dog walking. The George Inn mentioned above is also dog friendly.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: The stones are part of the Medway Megaliths, a series of Early Neolithic chambered long barrows and megalithic monuments located in the lower valley of the River Medway, near Chatham. You can explore some of the other sites on the Medway Megaliths Walk. This circular route can be picked up a few miles to the east at Blue Bell Hill near Burham. It visits the Coffin Stone, Kit's Coty House and Little Kit's Coty House, constructed circa 4000 BCE. For more walks in the area see the North Downs Walks page.
